Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrative Synthetic Biology: A Scalable Framework for Modular Multilevel Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
There have been recent and notable advances in the field of computer-aided tools for synthetic circuit design at the system level. While most approaches focus on providing visualization and simulation capabilities for the users to explore, there is a lack of a much needed end-to-end integrated framework capable of automated optimization of synthetic circuits based on user-defined constraints. The goal of the proposed project is to develop an integrated synthetic biology framework and tools for the automated systems-level design of mixed-signal synthetic circuits. This framework will serve as a computational tool for synthetic biologists and will lay the theoretical foundations for system level synthetic circuit design.

The project will explore a global optimization platform with both approximate and exact techniques for finding the optimal set of parts for any given configuration, which will provide guarantees on the optimality, reproducibility or bounds of the solution. This work will explore matching past validated designs to the circuit at hand, by employing graph-querying and graph partitioning algorithms that will transform the original design to equivalent graphs which can be solved efficiently. This will promote modular and reusable designs, and result in an increase in the level of achievable complexity and a decrease in the cost of construction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project started with the following question in mind: can the design process of synthetic gene circuits be as fast and reliable as those of cars and aircrafts? To achieve that, you need a sufficient database of parts that work well with each other and with well-characterized properties; a model thas describes both how parts interact and the system as a whole; and a way to evaluate how well your final design behaves once you build it, given the specs. Over the course of the project, the students and postdocs that worked on this challenge, developed the tools and resources for this task. First, they created a parts and modules database (PAMDB.com), which includes more than 700 parts curated from the published Synthetic Biology literature the past twenty years. Since characterizing their kinetic parameters is not feasible due to the time and money it would take, the team create the algorithms and methods to infer these parameters from the published data, tables and plots. Then the team created a univesal, succinct model to capture the interaction of the different parts (and part types, such as a transcription factor gene with a promoter sequence) and a CAD tool (SBROME) to design and simulate analog synthetic gene circuits, the same way that tools like Candence and Mentor Graphics do for VLSI circuits. The final step was to create an integrated model of the chassis, which in this case was the bacterium Escherichia coli, so that we can predict how the a specific strain and the synthetic circuit would behave under a specific environment (medium, stress, other environmental conditions). To do that, the team created the multi-omics database of E. coli (ECOMICS.com) and one of the most sophisticated mutli-omics models (MOMA) that leverages data from transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics and fluxomics to predict phenotypic traits, such as growth, given a strain and the environmental conditions in which it would grow. Since data would be scarce and inconsistent often, the ECOMICS database was augmented with RNA-Seq and growth measurement data over hundreds of experiments that we performed in our wet lab. Forward evaluation of the predictive model and a cascade circuit have demonstrated that although the methods are still crude and we are far from the performance metrics we see in other industries, we now have an engineering and structured way to design circuits beyond random trial and error and following legacy designs.

This project led to more than a dozen publications, and training of more than two dozen undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdocs, with many currently leading labs, working in the biotechnology and computer industry. It helped with curriculum development of courses in the area of Synthetic Biology, Bioinformatics and Machine Learning in Biology. And, equally importantly, it showed how we can develop, apply, and evaluate solutions following engineering principles in the promising field of synthetic biology that can evetually lead to solutions that accelerate the product life-cycle in an exponential way.
